title: Promised Lands: Slavery, Literature, and Modernity in Russia and the United States
xlist:
Same As: AMST 683, section 01
Same As: CPLT 571, section 01
Same As: RUSS 326, section 01
description: Close, comparative, contextualized examination of literary and other forms of cultural production associated with U.S. slavery and Russian serfdom. Special attention is paid to the relation between bondage and national, cultural, and personal identity; the role of bondage in definitions of "aesthetic experience" in the pre- and post-emancipation periods; the relation between literacy and the literary; literature of protest in the two countries; and connections between geographical and subjective space within cultures of enslavement. We examine works by Pushkin, Aksakov, Gogol, CrÃ¨vecoeur, Radishchev, Karamzin, Goncharov, Tolstoy, Kennedy and the "plantation novelists," Stowe, Melville, Turgenev, slave and serf autobiographers, freedman's textbooks, Fet, Page, Chesnutt, and Bunin; historical treatments by Kolchin, Genovese, and others; theoretical works by Said, Jameson, Bakhtin, and others; and Steve McQueen's film 12 Years a Slave. Requirements: in-class presentations and research paper. No knowledge of Russian required.
